info: From English, viking. Apparently, a prominent hotel owner in Japan visited European hotels for inspiration and was impressed by their buffet-style meals. This was a new concept in Japan. When asked what it should be called, he somewhat arbitrarily chose 'viking,' as it gave a strong European image
From the name of the American company E.H. Hotchkiss Company
From the German physicist's name, Wilhelm Röntgen. He won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1901 for producing and detecting X-rays
From English, after service (和製英語)
From German, Eis. Or from English, ice
From German, Eis. Or from English, ice

word.english_meaning: short for アメリカンフトボール: Ame(rican) foot(ball)

info: From English, american dog (和製英語)

word.english_meaning: anime. Comes from アニメーション (animation). The term 'anime' has been reborrowed into English with a meaning of 'Japanese animation;' however, in Japanese, the term refers to all animation)

info: From English, アニメーション (animation)

word.english_meaning: anime song, most often the theme. From アニメソング ani(me) + son(g)
apartment, flat (UK). アパート usually refers to small two-story wood-structure buildings, not multistory complexes as in the US usage. This would be マンション (mansion)

info: From Japanese, アルバイト (arubaito), which is from German, Arbeit

From Dutch/German, Bier, or English, beer

info: From English, cabin attendant (is this 和製英語? Maybe). In Japanese, this is also referred to as 'C.A.'

motor vehicle driver. Also, a screwdriver
drifting (when a car is in a controlled skid)
(1) to cheer on a player in a sports competition; (2) to express support for a candidate in an election
often used to mean 'Do your best!' or 'I'll do my best.'
the Nintendo Entertainment System. Also a catch-all term by the older generation for any gaming console.
fetch (computer jargon): to fetch an instruction from main memory when a microprocessor executes a command
four ball walk, ball four (baseball term)
to purchase an item before its official release date

to search for something on Google; to 'google'

high colla(r) (1920s slang). a person who was devoted to Western fashions, trends and values.

locking one's car keys inside of one's car
jingisukan (Mongolian-style barbecue with cut lamb and vegetables)

juice, soda, or energy drinks, regardless of whether they contain any juice

can (e.g. tin can, or drink can)
